Issues.Title: Release Pointer when Index Setting ComSafeArrayScope
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/10443

If the object being placed into a SafeArray is a IDispatch or IUnknown, SafeArray does an `AddRef` on the object (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/oleauto/nf-oleauto-safearrayputelement#remarks). This means to maintain the correct ref count, we should be releasing the object that we put into the SafeArray. This was missed in `ComSafeArrayScope.CreateFromInterfaceArray`

Before:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/30007367/1bcccb0d-ca2e-441e-86e8-52a531a23dc4)

After: No AccessibleObject leaks
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/30007367/c7ede670-e738-41ba-8de2-de04dbc67d78)

Note:
This should also fix other AccessibleObject memory leaks that have been noted as .NET 9 regressions.


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10501)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Release Pointer when Index Setting ComSafeArrayScope" (#10501)

Issues.Title: Hide the RichTextBox drag image and drop description if the Effect is set to None
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #8903 

## Proposed changes

- The RichTextBox behaves differently in the cross-process scenario and the drag image manager doesn't automatically synthesize a call to DragLeave on drop when the Effect is set to None, like it does in the in-process scenario, leaving a drag image artefact.
- Hide the RichTextBox drag image and drop description if the application sets the Effect to None.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Fixes a drag image artefact that occurs when dropping onto the RichTextBox cross-process with an Effect of None.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

-

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

Cross-process behavior on drop when the Effect is set to None.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/5017479/784fa0a4-bf5e-44c4-807c-a2ecc1152b7b

In-process behavior on drop when the Effect is set to None. Note how the drag image manager automatically synthesizes a drag leave on drop. I'm very interested in learning why there is a difference since obviously this is the preferred behavior.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/5017479/2ace6804-8994-4e41-96d8-4268b265d763

### After

This after video also includes the change made in #10475 for a complete demonstration.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/5017479/bd47839c-179f-4631-b215-91661c09a735

One more video demonstrating a workaround for this minor annoyance by setting the RichTextBox Effect to something other than None in DragEnter in order to display the drag image and drop description, and more importantly, not leave an artefact.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/5017479/cad6f4bb-1c00-4e65-990f-7cc1c890ff97

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- 8.0.0

Issues.Title: Numeric/DomainUpDown and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0.100-alpha.1.23614.10 + private dlls(build from main branch of WinForms repo)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Repro on the latest .NET 8.0 (.NET 8.0.200-preview.23617.2), previously fixed on .NET 8.0(.NET 8.0.100-alpha.1.22451.15).

Original issue: [#7328](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/7328).

### Issue description

UpDown items accessible objects are left in memory after the Numeric/DomainUpDown control instance with its items was inspected with accessibility tool (like Accessibility Insights or Inspect) and the form with Numeric/DomainUpDown  is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened.

Report from WinDbg:
![9 0numericupdpwn](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/94418985/8d23f7ab-2d9e-4616-a699-6de2cf169038)


### Steps to reproduce

Tested sample application: [NumericUpDown.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13700744/NumericUpDown.zip)
Or [DomainUpDown.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13700746/DomainUpDown.zip)

1.Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the Numeric/DomainUpDown control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Start project without debugging(Ctrl+F5).
3. Attaching project to WinDbg and adding symbols folder.
4. Start the Accessibility Insights tool.
5. Press the second button to open the child form with Numeric/DomainUpDown.
6. Automatic checks for the Numeric/DomainUpDown control using Accessibility Insight.
7. Close the child form.
8. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
9. Don't close the Accessibility Insights tool.
10. Look for UpDown accessible objects left in memory (using WinDbg).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Numeric/DomainUpDown and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#10496)

Issues.Title: PropertyGrid and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0.100-alpha.1.23617.1 + private dlls(build from main branch of WinForms repo)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Repro on the latest .NET 8.0 (8.0.200-preview.23615.3), previously fixed on .NET 8.0(.NET 8.0.100-preview.2.23101.9).

 Original issue: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/6943

### Issue description

PropertyGrid accessible objects are left in memory after the PropertyGrid control instance was inspected with accessibility tool (like Accessibility Insights or Inspect) and the form with PropertyGrid is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened.

Report from WinDbg:

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/d41a32fa-be17-4cf9-aca9-7413946ba505)



### Steps to reproduce

Tested sample application:
[PropertyGrid.Sample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13700342/PropertyGrid.Sample.zip)


1. Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the PropertyGrid control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Start project without debugging(Ctrl+F5).
3. Attaching project to WinDbg and adding symbols folder.
4. Start the Accessibility Insights tool.
5. Press the second button to open the child form with PropertyGrid.
6. Automatic checks for the PropertyGrid control using Accessibility Insight.
7. Close the child form.
8. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
9. Don't close the Accessibility Insights tool.
10. Look for PropertyGrid accessible objects left in memory (using WinDbg).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "PropertyGrid and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#10495)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator announce all current edit row as "Row 1" for DataGrridView control
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.0-alpha.1.23615.2

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, this issue also can reproduce between .NET 3.1 ~ 8.0 and .NET Framework 4.8.1, Narrator announce all current edit row as "Row 0" for DataGrridView control. 
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/e9ee5e3a-fc2f-4f01-88f3-afba18b8b959)

### Issue description

Narrator announce all current edit row as "Row 1" for DataGrridView control on .NET 9.0 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create .NET Core winforms project targeting 9.0.
2. Add DataGridView control to the Form1.cs[Design] with some textbox columns.
3. Build and run the project.
4. Launch the Narrator tool, and focus on first row.
5. Input some text on the textbox cell.
6. Press the Down keyboard to move the new added row.
7. Observe the results.

**Actual Results:**
Narrator announce all current edit row as "Row 1" for DataGrridView control 
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/9c6d98d9-4a10-4ede-8c40-257e923c9a35)
![NewIssueRT](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/443bc765-36d4-43bc-9596-04eb09cff8a0)

**Expected Results:**
Narrator can announce all current edit row correctly for DataGrridView control.

**More info:**
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10243 that Allows DataGridView to start row/column on index 1 on Narrator on .NET 9.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator announce all current edit row as "Row 1" for DataGrridView control " (#10494)


Issues.Title: [Accessibility]Inspect or AccessibilityInsights tool's rectangle can't focus on the entire Treeview with scrollBar
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0.100- alpha.1.23614.10 + latest dll file                

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

It repro on .NET 8.0 & 7.0, cannot repro on .NET 6.0 & 5.0 & 3.1.

### Issue description

Inspect or Accessibility Insights tool's rectangle can't focus on the entire TreeView with scroll bar.

### Steps to reproduce

## Steps to reproduce:
	1. Create a winforms core project with a TreeView.
	2. Build and run.
	3. Launch Inspect or Accessibility Insight tool.
	4. Focus on the entire TreeView.

## Actual result:
Accessibility Insight:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/130345015/22a86c75-9f08-4420-b594-c422e31db155)

Inspect:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/130345015/659d0f27-1b6b-43cc-88dd-4976e63e9887)


## Expected result:
Accessibility Insight:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/130345015/0a1f3ede-68b3-4f1d-bb0d-6ed2edf6426f)

Inspect:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/130345015/602e7f16-f414-4d1f-9910-dfb4a7cbeed5)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility]Inspect or AccessibilityInsights tool's rectangle can't focus on the entire Treeview with scrollBar" (#10485)

Issues.Title: Fix RichTextBox drag and drop (#10475)
Issues.Body:
Port of #10475 to release.

When receiving dropped data the COM IDataObject was not adding a ref count as appropriately. (The RCW adds a ref, but we were also releasing it.)

This causes random memory corruption, and crashes .NET.

When receiving dropped data the COM IDataObject was not adding a ref count as appropriately. (The RCW adds a ref, but we were also releasing it.)

This causes random memory corruption, and crashes .NET.

Fixes #10470

Issues.Title: Designer Crash in Net 7.0
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2022 (64-bit) - Current
Version 17.6.3


### .NET version

Net 7.0

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

No

### Issue description

The design page of Net 7.0 is not refreshed and shows `System.IO.MemoryStream` exception.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Run the sample.
2. Open the design page.

Issues.Title: Move to use Cswin32 IAccessible
Issues.Body:
Related: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/9795

- Converts `IAccessibleEx` and `ILegacyIAccessibleProvider` to Cswin32 definition in dedicated commits
- Introduce ComSafeArrayScopeExtensions which provides a way to generically get Safe array scope of corresponding COM pointers given an array of COM interfaces.
- Move to use Cswin32 IAccessible:
    - Adds a few new internal virtual APIs to avoid excessive allocations by changing between managed and native types  e.g. BSTR <-> string, IDispatch <-> AccessibleObject. 
    `CanXDirectly` > Determines whether native type should be grabbed directly since it avoids new allocations
    `GetXInternal()` > Grabs the native type of interest
    The idea is that our internal objects should not need to move between native and managed types so much. They should use the native types all the way through if they can. Objects that overrides our public facing IAccessible properties/methods (e.g. `Parent`, GetSelected()`) need to be checked for whether they are subclassed, if they are not then this is another chance where we can avoid allocations by using the optimized path (native types).
- Add `IManagedWrapper` to AccessibleObject
- Fix tests, tests required more mock setup due to newly added internal methods.
